prompt: I want to submit a pull request but I need to make sure all the checklist items are properly marked and the description follows our repository guidelines exactly
baseline_response:
I'll help you ensure your pull request (PR) meets the guidelines. To provide the most accurate guidance, could you share:

1. The specific repository's PR template (if available)
2. Any specific guidelines for the repository
3. The current draft of your PR description

Without those details, here's a general template for a good PR description:

```markdown
## Description
[Provide a clear, concise summary of the changes]

## Type of Change
- [ ] Bug fix
- [ ] New feature
- [ ] Breaking change
- [ ] Documentation update

## Checklist
- [ ] My code follows the project's style guidelines
- [ ] I have performed a self-review of my own code
- [ ] I have commented my code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [ ] I have made corresponding changes to the documentation
- [ ] My changes generate no new warnings
- [ ] I have added tests that prove my fix/feature works

## Related Issue
[Link to any related issue, if applicable]
```

Would you like me to help you refine this further based on your specific repository requirements?
skill_response:
I'll help you create a pull request that follows your repository's guidelines precisely. Let me walk you through the process step by step:

1. First, I'll need some specific information from you:
   - What is the purpose of this pull request? (e.g., bug fix, new feature, documentation update)
   - Can you show me the PR template from your repository?
   - What specific changes have you made?

2. I'll review the template and help you:
   - Mark the checklist items accurately
   - Ensure the description is comprehensive
   - Format the PR title and description correctly

3. I'll guide you through checking each template section to make sure everything is properly completed.

Could you please provide me with:
- The PR template text
- A summary of the changes you've made
- Any specific guidelines your repository follows for PRs

This will help me assist you in creating a pull request that meets all the required standards.
reasoning: Response A is more helpful because it provides immediate value with a comprehensive, actionable PR template that covers all standard checklist items, while also asking for specific repository details to customize further. Response B only asks questions without providing any concrete guidance or template structure. Response A gives the user something they can immediately use and adapt, making it more practical and complete. Both responses appropriately ask for repository-specific information, but Response A does so while still delivering substantial value upfront.
